samples.prompt: Write the opening scene of a novel. A woman in her thirties arrives at her childhood home after many years away. The house has been sold and she has one day to collect what remains of her family's belongings. Begin as she approaches the house. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The house came into view the way a thought does when you’ve been trying not to think it—sudden, complete, impossible to look away from. She slowed the car though there was no reason to, no traffic, no one watching. The road had narrowed since she last drove it, or perhaps it had always been this narrow and she’d grown used to wider things. The maples along the curb were taller, their branches knitting together overhead so that the street felt tunneled, hushed. Sunlight filtered through in pale coins that slid across the windshield and disappeared.

She parked across the street, engine ticking as it cooled, and sat with her hands on the wheel. The house was painted a different color now. Not the chalky blue her father had insisted was cheerful, but a careful gray with white trim that looked newly scrubbed, respectable. A realtor’s sign leaned against the porch railing, turned sideways as if embarrassed to still be there. SOLD was stamped across it in red, the letters loud even at a distance.

She got out of the car and the air met her with a smell she had forgotten she knew: damp leaves, old wood, something metallic. Autumn had always arrived early here, like an apology. She crossed the street slowly, feeling the unevenness of the pavement through the thin soles of her shoes. At the curb she hesitated, absurdly, as if there might be a rule against stepping onto that lawn now.

The grass was shorter than she remembered. Or perhaps it was the same and she had been smaller then, running barefoot until her mother shouted about ticks. She walked up the path, counting the stones without meaning to—one, two, three—until she reached the porch. The boards were newer, the railings straightened. The wind chimes her mother had loved were gone, replaced by a single potted plant with stiff, glossy leaves. Someone else’s attempt at welcome.

She set her bag down and looked for the key. It was heavier than keys had any right to be, a relic with teeth worn smooth. She’d found it last week in a jar at the back of her kitchen drawer, mixed in with takeout menus and dead batteries, and for a moment she’d been unsure what it was. Now her hand closed around it as if it had been waiting there all along.

The lock resisted, then gave. The door opened into a dimness that felt intentional, like a held breath. She stood on the threshold and let her eyes adjust. The smell inside was different from outside—dust and old paper, a sweetness that might have been rot or memory. The walls were bare where photographs had once climbed the staircase in uneven rows: birthdays, graduations, a cousin’s wedding. The nail holes remained, a constellation only she would read.

She stepped in, the door clicking shut behind her with a finality that made her chest tighten. The foyer seemed smaller. Everything did. The coat closet stood open, empty except for a single wire hanger that spun slightly, ticking against the rod. She reached out and stilled it with her fingers.

She had been given one day. Twenty-four hours to collect what remained of her family’s belongings, as if a life could be portioned so neatly. The lawyer had said it kindly, with a voice trained to smooth sharp things. Most of it had been sold or donated already. Furniture, appliances, the detritus of decades. What remained were items no one else had wanted, or known what to do with. Boxes in the basement. A dresser in the attic. Papers.

She walked into the living room. The carpet was gone, replaced by polished wood that reflected the windows like dark water. She remembered lying on that floor during thunderstorms, counting the seconds between flash and thunder, convinced that if she got the number right nothing bad could happen. The fireplace was still there, though the mantle was bare. No ceramic birds. No clock that chimed the wrong hour.

On the far wall, a rectangle of lighter paint marked where the couch had been. She laughed once, a short sound that surprised her. It echoed, then fell flat. She pressed her lips together and moved on.

The kitchen was brighter, the cabinets new, white, impersonal. The table was gone. She could see it anyway, scarred and solid, the place where homework had been spread and arguments staged. She touched the counter, cool beneath her palm, and felt an irrational urge to apologize.

Upstairs, the staircase creaked in the same places it always had. She paused on the landing, listening. The house made small sounds—settling, adjusting to her weight—as if recognizing her after a long absence. Or perhaps she was projecting. She had become good at that.

Her old bedroom door was closed. She rested her hand on the knob and thought, briefly, of turning around, of leaving everything as it was, untouched. The thought passed. She opened the door.

The room was stripped down to its bones. No posters, no bed, no desk by the window. The walls bore faint shadows where things had once been, a palimpsest of who she had been at twelve, at sixteen. Sunlight fell across the floor in a familiar angle, and for a moment time did something strange, folding in on itself. She stood there, thirty-six years old, with a day ahead of her and a house that was no longer hers, and felt the weight of both settle into place.

She closed the door gently behind her and began.

samples.prompt: Write a scene from a novel. Two old friends meet by chance at a train station. One is departing, the other arriving. They have not spoken in years due to a falling out over a business venture. Write their conversation and its aftermath. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The station smelled of hot metal and old coffee, a place of departures disguised as a place of waiting. Anna stepped down from the train with her coat slung over one arm, scanning the platform for the familiar square sign of the taxi rank. She was already rehearsing the meeting ahead—what she’d say, what she wouldn’t—when she saw him.

Mark stood near the departure board, a leather duffel at his feet, hands in his pockets as if he might float away without the weight. His hair was more gray than she remembered, and thinner. He had the same habit of leaning slightly forward, as though listening for something only he could hear.

For a moment neither of them moved. The board clattered overhead, cities rearranging themselves in bright orange letters.

“Anna,” he said first, like he was testing whether her name still worked.

“Mark.” She let the word land between them. “I didn’t know you were—”

“Leaving,” he said, nodding toward the tracks. “Ten minutes.”

She laughed once, sharply. “Of course you are.”

He smiled at that, the old reflex. It faded quickly. “I didn’t know you were coming back.”

“Neither did I,” she said. “Until yesterday.”

They stood there, the years pressing close, filling the silence with things neither of them had said. Around them, people embraced, argued, checked their phones. A whistle blew somewhere down the platform.

“You look well,” Mark said.

“So do you,” Anna replied, though she wasn’t sure it was true. “Where are you going?”

“West,” he said. “For good, I think.”

“Running again?”

He flinched, just a little. “I don’t see it that way.”

“No,” she said. “You never did.”

Another pause. He shifted his weight, glanced at the board, then back at her. “I heard the café closed.”

“It did,” she said. “Five years ago.”

“I’m sorry.”

She studied his face, looking for something—guilt, maybe, or regret—but found only tiredness. “Are you?”

He exhaled. “Yes. I was then, too. Even if I didn’t know how to say it.”

“That didn’t stop you from saying plenty of other things.”

“I know.”

The memory rose uninvited: the cramped office above the café, the spreadsheets, the raised voices. His certainty like a blade. Her name left off the final paperwork.

“You cut me out,” she said quietly. “After everything.”

He swallowed. “I thought I was saving it. Saving us.”

“You saved yourself.”

He nodded. “Probably.”

The announcement came then—his train, boarding. He didn’t move.

“I should have called,” he said. “After it fell apart.”

“Yes,” she said. “You should have.”

“I didn’t know what I’d say.”

“That’s funny,” she said. “You always knew before.”

He smiled, a ghost of it. “I know.”

They watched a conductor walk past, checking tickets. Mark bent to pick up his bag, then straightened again, as if unwilling to let the motion finish.

“Do you ever think about it?” he asked. “About how it might’ve gone?”

“Sometimes,” Anna said. “Mostly I think about how I trusted you.”

He winced. “I didn’t deserve that.”

“No,” she agreed. Then, after a moment, “But I gave it anyway.”

The boarding call sounded again, sharper now.

“I’m glad I ran into you,” he said. “Even like this.”

She considered that. “I don’t know if glad is the word I’d use.”

He nodded, accepting it. “Fair.”

For a second, it seemed like he might reach for her, the way he used to—an arm around her shoulders, a familiar anchoring. He stopped himself.

“If you’re ever out west,” he said, fumbling for a card in his pocket, then thinking better of it. “Well. You know.”

“I do,” she said, though she wasn’t sure she did at all.

He lifted his bag. “Take care, Anna.”

“You too, Mark.”

He turned, walked toward the train. At the door, he hesitated, looked back. She raised a hand, not quite a wave. He nodded once and stepped inside.

The doors closed. The train pulled away, metal screaming softly against metal, until it was gone and the platform felt suddenly too wide.

Anna stood there long enough for the crowd to thin, for the departure board to reshuffle itself again. Then she walked toward the exit, the city unfolding ahead of her.

Outside, the air was colder than she expected. She breathed it in, steadying herself. The past had not resolved itself neatly, had not apologized or forgiven. It had merely passed through, like a train on the wrong track.

She adjusted her coat and hailed a taxi.

As the station receded behind her, Anna thought—not for the first time—that some endings did not come with closure. Some simply left you standing on the platform, still holding the ticket, surprised by the quiet that followed.

samples.prompt: Write a scene from a novel. A middle-aged man sits in a hospital waiting room while his father undergoes surgery. He reflects on their relationship while observing other families around him. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The waiting room smelled faintly of disinfectant and burnt coffee, a smell that seemed designed to remind you of time—how it lingered, how it refused to move. Daniel sat with his hands folded between his knees, his jacket draped over the plastic chair beside him like a concession to comfort he didn’t quite believe in. Somewhere beyond the double doors, behind walls painted an optimistic blue, his father lay opened and sleeping, entrusted to people Daniel would never meet.

The clock above the reception desk ticked too loudly. Each second landed with a small, arrogant certainty.

Daniel had been here for three hours. Or four. Time had blurred into a single, long inhale he couldn’t release. He watched the doors each time they swung open, even though he knew the surgeon wouldn’t appear until there was something to say—good or bad. The not knowing was the hardest part. It left too much room for memory.

Across from him, a young couple sat pressed together, their fingers interlaced so tightly it looked painful. The woman’s eyes were red; the man kept rubbing his thumb along the back of her hand, the same small motion over and over, like a ritual. To Daniel’s left, an older woman sat alone, her purse clutched to her chest, lips moving silently as if she were reciting a prayer she had memorized long ago. A family with two small boys occupied the corner: one child sprawled on the floor with toy cars, the other asleep against his mother’s shoulder. Life, apparently, did not stop just because someone might be dying.

Daniel shifted in his seat and felt the ache in his lower back flare. Middle-aged, his doctor liked to say, with a half-smile that tried to make the word sound neutral. Old enough to know better. Old enough to regret.

His father, Robert, had never liked hospitals. “Too many people waiting for bad news,” he’d once said, years ago, when Daniel was young and indestructible and his father still seemed unbreakable. Robert had been a man of few words and firm opinions, a man who believed that showing up on time and paying your bills counted as love, whether anyone felt it or not.

They had never been close, not in the way Daniel saw other fathers and sons. There were no fishing trips, no long talks about life. Their conversations had been practical, transactional. How’s work. How’s the car running. Did you see the game. Affection, if it existed, was implied rather than expressed. When Daniel had moved out, his father had helped load the boxes without comment, then stood in the driveway and said, “Drive safe,” as if that encompassed everything else.

Daniel used to think that was enough. Or he told himself it was.

The doors opened and a nurse stepped out, calling a name that wasn’t his. The young couple stood, hope flaring and then dimming as they realized the mistake. They sat back down, the woman wiping her cheeks with the heel of her hand. Daniel looked away, embarrassed by the intimacy of their grief.

He wondered what his father was thinking now, if thinking was even possible under anesthesia. Would Robert be afraid, if he were awake? The thought unsettled Daniel more than it should have. His father afraid felt like a violation of the natural order, like seeing a mountain tremble.

There had been words left unsaid between them. Daniel could catalog them easily, as if they were items in a drawer he refused to open. I needed you. I was proud of you. I’m sorry. Love was somewhere in there too, he supposed, though it had never been spoken aloud. They had both been stubborn men, mistaking silence for strength.

The older woman across the room caught Daniel’s eye and offered a thin, sympathetic smile. He nodded back, surprised by the sudden warmth behind his eyes. Strangers, he thought, were sometimes kinder because they had no history to complicate things.

He imagined the surgeon’s hands, steady and precise, working through muscle and bone. He imagined the possibility of waking his father later, of hearing his gruff voice complain about the food or the noise or the indignity of it all. The thought brought an unexpected comfort. Annoyance, he realized, would be a gift.

Daniel leaned back and let his head rest against the wall. He remembered being twelve, breaking his arm after falling from a tree. His father had driven him to the emergency room in silence, jaw clenched, knuckles white on the steering wheel. Later, after the cast was on, Robert had placed a hand on Daniel’s shoulder—just for a moment—and said, “You scared me.” It was the closest they had ever come to a confession.

The clock ticked. The doors remained closed.

Daniel sat there among strangers and prayers and plastic chairs, understanding at last that love didn’t always announce itself clearly. Sometimes it waited, quiet and stubborn, like a man in a hospital waiting room, hoping for the chance to finally say what should have been said all along.

samples.prompt: Write a passage in the Gothic tradition. A scholar discovers a hidden chamber in an old library that contains manuscripts no one has read in centuries. As they begin to read, they realize the texts describe events that have not yet occurred. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The library had always seemed to breathe more deeply at night. By day it was a place of dust and habit, of scholars bent beneath the lamps, of footsteps softened by centuries of worn stone. But when the hour grew late and the great doors were barred, the building exhaled its secrets. Candles guttered in unseen drafts, and the shadows among the shelves lengthened into shapes that suggested intention.

It was in such an hour that Elias Morcant made his discovery.

He had come to the Collegium’s oldest wing to consult a ledger cited in a footnote so obscure that no one alive could recall seeing the volume itself. The wing lay beneath the newer floors like a buried organ, its ceiling low, its air chill and faintly metallic. Elias worked alone, the flame of his lamp trembling as he traced the spines of books bound in skins long cured of their former softness. Time pressed upon him there, not as a memory but as a weight.

When his fingers brushed a shelf that rang hollow, he paused. The sound was subtle, a dull echo where there should have been only wood and stone. He pressed again, more firmly. The shelf shifted inward with a sigh, releasing a breath of air that smelled of old ink and something darker, like rain trapped underground.

Behind the shelf yawned a narrow opening.

Elias hesitated, struck by the unacademic certainty that he was being watched. The sensation was absurd; he was alone in the deepest vault of the library. Yet his skin prickled as though an unseen eye had opened. He lifted the lamp and stepped through.

The chamber beyond was small and circular, its walls lined with iron racks instead of wood. Manuscripts lay there not in the familiar codex form but as bundled sheaves, scrolls, and stitched folios whose bindings bore no titles. The lamp’s light revealed ink that gleamed too darkly, as if it had never fully dried.

No catalogue marked this place. No marginal hand had claimed ownership or authorship. The silence was complete, heavy enough that Elias became conscious of his own breathing, the soft rasp of it sounding indecently loud.

He selected a manuscript at random. The vellum was cool, almost cold, and as he opened it a faint tremor passed through his hands. The script was precise, angular, written in a Latin whose forms were archaic yet unsettlingly clear. He read the opening lines—and frowned.

They described the Collegium library as it stood now, not as it had stood centuries ago. The wording captured details too recent, too specific: the stained-glass window repaired after the fire of ’92; the cracked gargoyle on the south parapet, broken in a storm Elias himself remembered.

A chill crept along his spine. He turned the page.

The text continued, methodical and unemotional, recounting events of the previous week. A debate in the refectory. A scholar’s sudden illness. Even Elias’s own arrival in the old wing that evening, rendered in a voice that neither condemned nor explained.

He laughed softly, the sound brittle. A hoax, perhaps—a clever forgery, though one requiring impossible foresight. Still, his eyes kept moving, dragged onward by a curiosity that had long ago learned to override caution.

The next page described tomorrow.

It spoke of a bell ringing at an unscheduled hour. Of smoke rising from the east tower. Of a name—Professor Aldwych—followed by a symbol Elias did not recognize but instinctively associated with finality.

Elias snapped the manuscript shut. The lamp flared as if in response, its flame stretching and then shrinking back. His heart hammered. Reason demanded that he leave, report the chamber, submit the texts to scrutiny. Yet another part of him—a quieter, older instinct—whispered that the act of reading had already implicated him.

Against his better judgment, he reached for another manuscript.

This one was thinner, its pages brittle. It began not with description but with a warning: Those who read become footnotes to the text. Elias swallowed and read on.

Here the prose shifted, less detached, more intimate. It described a man of learning who believed knowledge to be a lantern against darkness, only to discover that some knowledge was a mirror instead. The details grew more precise with each paragraph: the man’s habits, his doubts, the faint scar on his left hand from a childhood accident Elias had never mentioned to anyone at the Collegium.

The final lines were unfinished.

A blank space yawned at the bottom of the page, as though awaiting ink.

Elias staggered back, his heel striking the iron rack. The manuscripts rustled softly, a sound like distant applause or dry leaves stirred by a wind he could not feel. Understanding dawned, slow and terrible. These texts were not merely predictive; they were participatory. The future they described was not fixed but fed—by attention, by belief, by the act of reading itself.

His gaze fell again upon the open page. The blank space seemed to darken, as if shadow pooled there. With a trembling hand, Elias raised the lamp closer.

Letters were forming.

They spelled his name.

A sudden certainty seized him: the chamber did not record the future so much as it required witnesses to complete it. Each reader became a conduit, their lives narrowed into narrative necessity. To leave now would not undo what had begun; the text had already accounted for his hesitation, his fear.

Footsteps echoed beyond the hidden shelf. Voices murmured—searching, perhaps, drawn by instinct or fate. Elias looked from the forming words to the manuscripts that surrounded him, centuries of unread prophecy waiting for eyes.

He understood then why the chamber had remained hidden. It was not secrecy that preserved it, but restraint.

As the letters finished themselves on the page, Elias lowered the lamp. In the darkness, the library breathed on, and the future, newly legible, quietly learned how to proceed.

samples.prompt: Write a passage in the Gothic tradition. A woman inherits a house in a coastal village. The locals refuse to speak of its history. On her first night, she hears sounds from a room that, according to the floor plans, should not exist. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
She arrived in the village at ebb tide, when the sea had withdrawn its bright tongue from the stones and left behind a glistening, kelp-strung silence. The driver set her trunk down without meeting her eyes, touched the brim of his cap, and drove away with undue haste. For a moment she stood alone on the narrow road, the house rising before her like a thought she had tried not to think.

It was called Blackthorn House, though no blackthorn grew nearby. The name had come to her in the solicitor’s letter, along with the revelation of an inheritance from a great-aunt she had met only once, long ago, and remembered chiefly for her hands—thin, cold, and smelling faintly of salt. The house crouched above the cliffs, its windows dark and unreflective, its roofline jagged against the low sky. Gulls wheeled and cried as if disputing ownership.

The villagers had been cordial in the stiff way of people who believed courtesy might fend off inquiry. When she asked after the house, conversation faltered. A woman weighing fish on a scale suddenly found fault with her sums; a man mending nets became deeply engrossed in his knots. No one contradicted her when she said she would be staying at Blackthorn House, but no one elaborated either. It was as though the name itself had drawn a veil across their mouths.

Inside, the air was cool and close, scented with old plaster and something medicinal. The entrance hall was narrower than she had expected, the ceiling low enough to press upon her thoughts. She lit the lamps one by one, revealing dark paneling and a staircase that rose, turned sharply, and vanished. The rooms unfolded in an orderly fashion: a parlor with tall windows facing the sea, a dining room whose long table bore the pale rings of vanished glasses, a kitchen sunk half below ground. Everything corresponded, more or less, to the floor plans she had studied on the train—yellowed blueprints folded and refolded until the creases seemed to hold the house together.

It was these plans that steadied her. They suggested that the house was comprehensible, a thing of measured angles and labeled spaces. She spread them out on the parlor table, smoothing them flat with a hand that trembled despite herself. First floor, second floor, attic: all accounted for. No surprises.

By nightfall the tide had turned. The sea breathed again, fuller now, its voice rising and falling against the cliff. She dined alone, then climbed the stairs to the bedroom she had chosen for its view. The wind worried at the windows. When she lay down, the mattress sighed as if relieved to have a weight upon it at last.

She did not know how long she slept before the sound woke her.

At first it seemed part of the sea’s restless speech—a shifting, a murmur. Then it resolved itself into something else: a measured rhythm, like a body moving with care in a confined space. There was the soft scuff of feet, the faint thud of something set down and lifted again. She sat up, heart racing, and listened. The sounds came from nearby, from behind the wall against which her bed was placed.

Impossible, she told herself. According to the plans, there was nothing there. Beyond that wall lay only the outer face of the house and the sheer drop to the rocks below.

The sounds continued. A door creaked open, slowly, with the patience of something that had learned not to hurry. She rose and took the lamp in her hand. Its light wavered as she crossed the room, casting her shadow tall and distorted upon the walls. She pressed her palm against the paneling. It was cold, solid. The noise persisted, closer now, intimate enough that she could hear breathing—shallow, deliberate.

She fetched the folded plans from her trunk and spread them on the bed, tracing the lines with her finger. Bedroom. Corridor. Stairwell. Nothing more. Yet when she held the paper up against the wall, aligning the corners as best she could, the sounds seemed to laugh softly at her certainty.

There was a narrow door she had not noticed before, half-concealed by a tapestry darkened with age. It had no handle, only a shallow depression worn smooth by touch. Her breath fogged in the cool air as she stared at it. The sounds paused, as if aware of her attention, then resumed—now unmistakably on the other side of this door.

She thought of the villagers’ silence, the way their eyes had slid away from her questions. She thought of her great-aunt’s hands, salt-scented and cold. The lamp flickered. The sea boomed far below, a vast, indifferent witness.

When she pressed her fingers into the hollow, the door yielded with a sigh. Beyond lay darkness deeper than the night outside, and the sense—not yet sight—of a space that should not be there, stretching inward, patient and expectant. The sounds ceased, replaced by a silence so complete it seemed to listen in return.

She stood on the threshold, plans crumpling in her other hand, and understood with a sudden, sinking clarity that the house had not been waiting empty all these years. It had been waiting for her.

samples.prompt: Write a passage in the Gothic tradition. A portrait painter is commissioned to create a likeness of an elderly aristocrat. During their sessions, the subject tells stories that seem impossible—events from centuries past, described as firsthand experience. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The letter arrived sealed in black wax impressed with a sigil I did not recognize—an ouroboros encircling a tower. It summoned me to Gravenhurst, a manor perched like a carrion bird above the estuary, and offered a fee so extravagant that prudence yielded at once to curiosity. I was to paint the portrait of Lord Alaric Fenmere, whose name, though ancient, had lately returned to whispered circulation among those who traded in titles and shadows.

I found him waiting in a high-ceilinged chamber whose windows admitted a light already old and yellowed, as if it had been stored for years in the walls before release. Fenmere sat in a carved chair, his hands folded over a cane of dark wood. He was elderly beyond question—his skin thin as parchment, his hair the color of frostbitten ash—yet his posture possessed a severe dignity, a spine unbowed by time.

“You will forgive the hour,” he said, without greeting. “I prefer the afternoon. Morning is too full of promise.”

I set up my easel. He watched with an intensity that prickled the back of my neck, as though he studied not my hands but the spaces between my thoughts. When at last I lifted my brush, he began to speak.

“Have you ever seen Constantinople?” he asked.

I replied that I had not.

“Pity. It was never so beautiful as on the eve of its fall. I stood on the walls when the cannons began to speak.”

I paused, brush hovering. “You mean,” I said carefully, “you have read—”

“No,” he interrupted, smiling thinly. “I mean I stood there. I recall the smell of pitch and the cries in Greek and Latin both. The sea glowed with fire.”

His voice was not theatrical. He spoke as one recalling a weathered inconvenience. I resumed painting, telling myself the old man indulged in fantasy, or metaphor. Yet as the days passed, his stories accumulated like sediment.

He spoke of the plague in Florence, of dancing corpses painted on chapel walls while the living fled. He described the coronation of a boy-king in Westminster whose name history had forgotten, the boy’s crown slipping sideways under its own weight. He remembered the night the first cathedral spire collapsed in an earthquake no chronicle recorded.

“These things are not written,” I said once, unable to restrain myself. “There is no record.”

He chuckled, a dry sound. “Records are selective. Survival is an editor.”

With each session, I noticed changes—not in him, but in the painting. The likeness resisted me. No matter how faithfully I rendered his features, the eyes refused to settle. They seemed to recede into shadow, as though the canvas itself recoiled from their depth. I scraped and repainted until the surface grew thick and scarred.

At night, I dreamed of standing before mirrors that showed not my reflection, but Fenmere’s face at different ages: young and cruel, middle-aged and weary, always watching.

One afternoon, as rain lashed the windows with desperate fingers, he spoke of a winter spent in a castle now sunk beneath the Baltic. “The ice sang at night,” he said. “It is a sound one never forgets, like glass remembering how to break.”

I set down my brush. “My lord,” I said, my voice trembling despite myself, “you speak as if you have lived—”

“Too long?” he supplied.

“Yes.”

He regarded me for a long moment. “Do you know why portraits endure?” he asked. “Not because they capture youth or beauty. They endure because they bind. They hold fast what would otherwise drift.”

A dreadful understanding crept over me. “You want more than a likeness.”

“Of course.” His gaze flicked to the canvas. “I require a witness.”

That night I crept back into the studio with a lantern. The portrait loomed, unfinished yet oppressive. In the lamplight, the painted eyes glistened wetly. For a heartbeat, I thought they moved.

I understood then the nature of his commission. He was not preserving himself; he was distributing himself, anchoring fragments of memory and being in oil and pigment, in stone and story, so that no single death could claim him whole.

At our final sitting, I painted with a frantic intensity, desperate to be done. Fenmere spoke no more. When I laid down my brush, the portrait was complete. It was magnificent—and utterly wrong. The eyes were mine.

“You see,” he said gently, rising with surprising ease, “time must be paid for.”

I fled Gravenhurst before dawn. The portrait remains there, I am told, hanging in the long gallery. Those who visit remark upon its strange vitality, how the subject seems almost to breathe.

As for me, I have begun to remember things I should not: the weight of armor on young shoulders, the sound of ice singing in the dark. When I look in the mirror, I sometimes glimpse a sigil faintly impressed upon my brow, like wax pressed too long ago to fully fade.

samples.prompt: Write an adventure narrative. A ship captain navigates through a dangerous strait during a storm. The crew must make split-second decisions as cargo shifts and rigging fails. Describe the physical struggle against the elements. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The storm rose like a wall, a bruised and boiling horizon that swallowed the last line of sunset as the ship approached the strait. Captain Mara Vale stood braced at the helm, boots planted wide, fingers locked around the worn spokes. The wind came shrieking down the channel, funneled between black cliffs that leaned toward one another like conspirators. Waves rebounded off stone and collided mid-channel, turning the sea into a chaos of crosshatching crests and sudden troughs. This was the Cutterwake Strait—narrow, treacherous, and alive with currents that twisted like snakes.

“Hands to stations!” Mara shouted, though the wind tore the words apart and flung them down the deck in tatters. The crew moved anyway, because they had learned the language of her posture: the set of her shoulders, the angle of her chin into the gale. The ship answered too, timbers groaning as if in protest. Rain hammered the deck in needles, slicking the planks until every step threatened to become a fall.

A wave struck the bow and burst upward, cold and heavy, knocking two sailors to their knees. One slid toward the scuppers, caught himself on a belaying pin, and hung there gasping, knuckles white. The ship rolled hard to port, then snapped back, masts whipping overhead. The topsails cracked like gunshots.

“Ease the fore!” Mara barked. “No—hold—hold it!” The current had them now, dragging the hull sideways toward a serrated outcrop that lurked just beneath the surface. The helmsman’s eyes were wide, fixed on Mara. She leaned into the wheel, feeling the ship’s reluctance, the weight of water pressing against the rudder like a stubborn hand.

Below decks came a sound that froze her blood: the low, sliding thunder of cargo shifting. Barrels broke their chocks and rolled, smashing into one another. The ship lurched again as weight migrated where it did not belong.

“Secure the hold!” someone shouted from the hatch.

“Too late for perfect,” Mara said. “Make it fast.”

A gust tore across the deck and ripped a line from its cleat. It lashed like a living thing, snapping against the rail and leaving a sailor clutching his arm, blood dark against the rain. The rigging sang a high, sick note as strain climbed past reason. Then something gave way aloft with a sound like tearing canvas and screaming wood.

“Main staysail’s gone!” came the cry.

“Cut it free!” Mara replied without hesitation. A second’s delay could pull the mast with it, and the strait would finish what the storm began. Knives flashed. Canvas, half-submerged, tugged at the ship like a drowning giant until the last line parted and it vanished into the froth.

The ship surged forward, lighter, but the relief was brief. A crosswave caught them broadside and heeled the deck until the sea rushed over the rail, cold as knives against skin. Mara tasted salt and iron. Her hands burned where the wheel tore at them, splinters biting deep. She welcomed the pain; it meant she still had control, however tenuous.

“Depth?” she shouted.

“Dropping fast!” came the answer. “Six fathoms—five!”

The cliffs loomed closer, their faces slick and gleaming, streaked with waterfalls that appeared and vanished in the rain. The wind howled through fissures, a thousand voices jeering. The ship shuddered as the keel brushed something unseen, a warning kiss that rattled teeth.

Mara’s mind narrowed to angles and timing. She watched the water, the way foam feathered and broke, the subtle tells of a hidden rock or a sudden set in the current. She counted heartbeats between waves, felt for the moment when the sea loosened its grip just enough to turn.

“Now!” she shouted. “Hard starboard!”

The crew heaved together, muscles straining, boots sliding. The wheel fought back, then yielded an inch, then another. The ship’s bow began to swing, slow as regret. A wave rose astern, towering and green, its crest blown white. It struck like a hammer, shoving the Cutterwake forward and through the turn. The hull screamed, but held.

Below, the cargo finished its ugly dance. Someone wedged a beam under a runaway crate; someone else took a barrel square in the thigh and went down, teeth clenched, refusing to cry out. They lashed and braced and prayed, hands numb, lungs burning.

Another spar cracked aloft. The foremast shivered but stayed standing. The storm spent itself in bursts now, savage but shorter, as if the strait itself were squeezing it dry. The current eased its sideways pull. The sound of water against stone softened, then fell away behind them.

When the sea finally opened and the channel widened, the wind slackened enough for breath. The rain thinned to a cold mist. The ship limped into deeper water, scarred but alive.

Mara leaned her forehead against the wheel for a moment, feeling the tremor leave her hands. Around her, the crew straightened, bruised and bleeding, faces lit with a fierce, quiet triumph. The strait lay behind them, still roaring, still hungry—but it had not taken them today.

samples.prompt: Write an adventure narrative. An expedition into unmapped jungle discovers ruins of a civilization unknown to history. As they explore deeper, they realize they are not alone. Write their first encounter with the ruins' guardians. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The jungle ended not with a clearing but with a hush.

Dr. Eliza Moreno felt it first—the way the cicadas fell silent as if a hand had been laid over the canopy. Sweat traced familiar paths down her spine as she pushed aside a curtain of leaves and stepped into shadow that did not belong to any tree. Stone rose before her, fitted without mortar, its surface softened by centuries of moss. A wall. Not Mayan, not Incan—nothing she had cataloged or dreamed of. The expedition’s machetes paused mid-swing. Even the river behind them seemed to hold its breath.

“Ruins,” whispered Jonah Pike, their logistics lead, with a grin that tried and failed to be irreverent. “You see the cut? Too precise.”

Eliza reached out, fingers hovering a centimeter from the stone. The carvings spiraled inward like coiled smoke, repeating a pattern of eyes and crescents she did not recognize. She traced one glyph with her gaze, mapping its rhythm. Unknown script. Unknown civilization. The jungle, as if resentful of their attention, let loose a single birdcall—sharp, warning.

They advanced through a breach where a tree had fallen, its roots wrenching open the wall like a wound. Inside, the air was cooler, layered with the scent of wet stone and something metallic. Sunlight fractured through the canopy and caught on pillars that stood like ribs, each etched with scenes of processions and beasts with too many joints. Their guide, Aro, lifted a hand.

“Listen,” he said softly.

There was a sound beneath the jungle’s murmur—a cadence, slow and deliberate, like breath counted by stone. Footsteps? No. Too measured. Eliza’s pulse climbed. She had read about the feeling explorers described upon realizing they had crossed from the map’s edge into the world’s memory. This was different. This felt reciprocal. Watched.

They passed beneath an archway whose keystone bore a face smoothed by time, eyes hollowed into darkness. The ground sloped downward into a plaza half-swallowed by roots. At its center rose a stepped platform, blackened as if fire had once kissed it and retreated. The cadence grew louder.

“Motion sensors?” Jonah murmured, absurdly.

Eliza shook her head. “Stone doesn’t breathe.”

Something shifted on the platform. A figure unfolded itself from shadow, tall and narrow, its surface matte as basalt. It was not carved; it was assembled, plates overlapping with the precision of a watch. Where a face should have been, a lattice of stone flexed, rearranging until two hollows aligned with Eliza’s eyes.

A second guardian stepped into view, then a third, forming a crescent around the platform. Each moved with the economy of things that had never needed to hurry.

Aro swore under his breath. He raised his palms, empty, and spoke in a tongue Eliza did not recognize, his voice trembling. The guardians did not respond.

The cadence resolved into a voice—not sound exactly, but pressure, a vibration that settled into Eliza’s bones and rearranged her thoughts until meaning emerged.

You have crossed the line of remembrance.

Jonah staggered, clutching his head. “Did—did anyone else—?”

Eliza nodded, swallowing. “We hear you.”

The nearest guardian tilted its head. Stone whispered against stone. Its surface rippled, glyphs flowing across it like schools of fish. Eliza’s breath caught as she recognized the same spiral she’d traced on the wall.

Names erode, the voice continued. We remain.

“We’re explorers,” Eliza said, choosing her words with care. “We didn’t know this place existed.”

A pause. The guardians’ hollows dimmed, then flared faintly, like embers coaxed back to life.

Ignorance is a common entry, came the reply. Intention decides the exit.

One guardian stepped forward. The ground shuddered with its weight. It extended an arm that split into facets, revealing an inner surface etched with scenes—cities rising, rivers redirected, people kneeling not in fear but in communion. Then fire. Collapse. A hand—stone or flesh, Eliza could not tell—reached toward a circle of stars.

“They were… advanced,” Jonah breathed. “They protected something.”

We protect balance, said the voice, sharper now. When flesh failed, we endured.

Aro lowered his hands. “We mean no harm,” he said. “We will leave.”

The guardian’s hollows fixed on him. Leaving is also a choice that changes the world.

Eliza felt the weight of centuries pressing in, the ethical calculus of discovery and silence. She thought of satellites and headlines, of looters and labs. She thought of knowledge as a fire that warmed and consumed.

“What do you want from us?” she asked.

The guardians shifted as one, plates aligning. The cadence slowed, deepened.

Witness, they said. And restraint.

A path opened between them, the stone floor glowing faintly, leading deeper into the ruins where the jungle had not yet reclaimed the past. Eliza met Jonah’s eyes. Fear warred with wonder, and wonder won.

They stepped forward, into the care of stone that remembered, knowing the world would never be the same—and that some truths, once seen, must be carried quietly, like a flame cupped against the wind.

samples.prompt: Write an adventure narrative. A pilot crash-lands in mountainous terrain. With limited supplies and an injured passenger, they must find a path to safety before winter storms arrive. Describe the first day's journey. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The plane went quiet before it went loud.

One moment the engine was a rough, coughing animal, the next it was a stunned silence so complete that Mara could hear her own breath inside the headset. The mountains rose ahead like a wall of teeth. She pushed the nose down, searching for a place to put them that wasn’t stone. Snow had already dusted the higher ridges; winter was practicing its grip.

They hit the ground in a sliding scream of metal and earth. The plane tore through scrub pine, the wings clipping branches like matchsticks. When it finally stopped, it did so crookedly, nose buried, tail lifted, one wing folded like a broken arm. Smoke drifted. Then nothing.

Mara forced her hands to open. Her fingers trembled as she pulled the headset free and turned in her seat. “Eli?”

The passenger’s eyes were open, unfocused. Blood streaked his temple where it had met the window. His right leg lay at an angle legs weren’t meant to take.

“I’m here,” he said, or tried to. The word came out thin.

“Don’t move.” She unbuckled herself, pain blooming in her ribs where the harness had caught her. She smelled fuel and made herself work faster, bracing the seat, helping Eli free. Outside, the air was cold and sharp, the kind that cut your lungs if you breathed too deep.

They dragged clear of the wreck before it could decide to burn. The mountains held them in a bowl of gray stone and late-autumn grass. Pines crowded the slopes, their shadows long even though the sun hadn’t yet reached its highest point. Clouds were already stacking over the peaks to the west.

Mara took inventory with the ruthless calm that training drilled into you when fear wanted to run the show. One pack from the back—emergency kit, a tarp, flares, a hand-crank radio that crackled with static and refused to find a voice. A few protein bars. A liter and a half of water. A knife. No satellite phone. No spare boots.

Eli’s leg was worse than she’d hoped. She set it as best she could, bit down on apologies, splinted it with scavenged aluminum and duct tape. He passed out halfway through and woke again with his jaw clenched and eyes wet but stubborn.

“We can’t stay,” she said once he was wrapped and warm in the tarp. “Storm’s coming. If snow drops, they won’t see us from the air.”

“How far?” he asked.

She looked at the land like it might answer her. A valley fell away to the south, a dark ribbon that could be water or shadow. Trees thickened there; valleys meant creeks, and creeks meant paths carved by gravity and hooves and maybe, if luck remembered them, people.

“Down,” she said. “Slow.”

They made a sled of the tarp, tying it to the pack straps. Mara leaned into the harness and felt her ribs complain, then fall into a rhythm. The ground was uneven, tufts of grass hiding stones that lurched the sled sideways. She learned to read the land with her feet, to test each step before committing weight.

The sun moved behind cloud, the light flattening. Cold crept in through her gloves. Eli dozed and woke, muttering apologies she waved away. Once, they startled a pair of deer that exploded from the brush, all legs and panic, leaving the smell of animal heat behind. The world felt too big and too empty at the same time.

They stopped at a trickle of water, half-hidden by rocks. Mara filtered, rationed, forced protein bars down past a mouth gone dry with effort. She checked the sky. The clouds had knitted together; snow whispered its intention.

The valley narrowed, then opened into a shelf where old stumps hinted at a logging road long since reclaimed. It wasn’t much—a depression, a line where plants grew differently—but it was a line, and lines meant someone had once wanted to go somewhere.

By late afternoon, her legs shook. The sled caught on roots, on stones, on nothing at all. She fell once, hard, and lay there listening to her heart hammer while the mountains watched without comment. Eli’s hand found her sleeve. “Mara,” he said. “We’re still moving.”

She laughed, a short bark that surprised her with its edge. She got up.

They made camp where the road dipped into trees that blocked the wind. She built a small fire, coaxing it from damp twigs and patience. The flames were meager but defiant. She hung the flares within reach and checked the radio again. Static. She pictured snow filling the bowl they’d left, erasing the plane, erasing the day.

As night came on, the cold sharpened. Stars pricked through breaks in cloud like holes in a tarp. Mara fed the fire and planned the morning—follow the road, listen for water, watch the sky. She thought of the distance they’d covered and the distance still waiting.

Eli slept, his breath shallow but steady. The mountains leaned in, ancient and indifferent. Winter was coming, yes—but not yet. Today, they had moved. That would have to be enough.

samples.prompt: Write a philosophical essay arguing a position on this question: Is certainty a virtue or a liability in intellectual life? Take a clear stance and defend it with examples and reasoning. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
Certainty as a Liability in Intellectual Life

Certainty is often praised as a virtue. We admire the confident scientist, the decisive leader, the philosopher who speaks without hesitation. Certainty seems to promise clarity, stability, and intellectual authority. Yet in intellectual life—where the aim is understanding rather than reassurance—certainty is more often a liability than a virtue. While provisional commitment and confidence have their place, certainty, understood as the conviction that one’s beliefs are beyond serious doubt, tends to hinder inquiry, distort judgment, and impoverish intellectual growth. Intellectual progress depends not on certainty, but on disciplined uncertainty.

To see why certainty is a liability, we must distinguish it from related but healthier attitudes. Confidence can coexist with openness to revision; certainty cannot. A confident thinker says, “This is my best view given the evidence.” A certain thinker says, “This is the truth, and alternatives are not worth considering.” The former invites dialogue and refinement; the latter closes the door. Intellectual life, however, thrives on doors remaining open.

One reason certainty is dangerous is that it prematurely ends inquiry. When a person is certain, questioning feels unnecessary or even threatening. This attitude is fatal to intellectual progress, which depends on sustained doubt and continual testing of assumptions. The history of science offers vivid examples. For centuries, Aristotelian physics was treated with near certainty in Europe. Because its principles were regarded as settled truth, anomalies were ignored or explained away. Only when figures like Galileo challenged this certainty—by insisting on observation and experiment rather than inherited authority—did physics advance. The obstacle was not ignorance, but excessive confidence hardened into certainty.

Certainty also fosters intellectual arrogance. When individuals or institutions believe they possess final answers, they often dismiss dissent not as disagreement but as error, ignorance, or bad faith. This is evident not only in dogmatic religious traditions but also in secular ideologies and academic orthodoxies. Marxism, for example, presented itself in some forms as a “scientific” and inevitable account of history. Where this certainty took hold, criticism was branded as reactionary or false consciousness, and intellectual pluralism suffered. Certainty, in such cases, does not merely block understanding; it justifies intellectual exclusion.

Moreover, certainty distorts how evidence is processed. Psychologists have repeatedly shown that humans are prone to confirmation bias: we seek evidence that supports what we already believe and discount evidence that challenges it. Certainty intensifies this bias. When a belief is held with certainty, contrary evidence is no longer evaluated on its merits but treated as a threat to be neutralized. The thinker becomes less a seeker of truth and more a defender of a position. Intellectual life degenerates into rationalization rather than reasoning.

By contrast, uncertainty can be an intellectual virtue. To live intellectually is not to float in perpetual indecision, but to hold beliefs with an awareness of their fallibility. This stance—sometimes called epistemic humility—acknowledges that human knowledge is limited, historically situated, and corrigible. Philosophers from Socrates to Karl Popper have emphasized this point. Socrates’ famous claim to wisdom consisted precisely in knowing that he did not know. Popper argued that science advances not by proving theories true with certainty, but by subjecting them to falsification and surviving error.

Importantly, rejecting certainty does not mean rejecting commitment or action. We must act, argue, and decide based on the best available reasons. But these commitments should be provisional rather than absolute. A doctor must choose a treatment; a judge must render a verdict; a citizen must vote. Yet in each case, intellectual virtue lies in remaining open to the possibility of mistake and willing to revise one’s views in light of new evidence. Certainty, by contrast, hardens decisions into identities and makes revision psychologically costly.

Some might object that certainty provides moral and intellectual stability. Without it, they argue, we risk relativism or paralysis. But this objection misunderstands the alternative. The opposite of certainty is not nihilism, but fallibilism: the view that knowledge is possible, meaningful, and action-guiding, even though it is never infallible. Indeed, many of our most reliable practices—science, law, and democratic deliberation—are built precisely on structured uncertainty: peer review, appeals, replication, and debate. These institutions assume error as a permanent possibility and design mechanisms to correct it.

In intellectual life, then, certainty is not a badge of strength but a warning sign. It signals the point at which belief stops listening. While confidence and commitment are necessary for thought and action, certainty undermines the very processes that generate understanding. A healthy intellectual life is marked not by unshakable conviction, but by the courage to revise one’s deepest beliefs. In this sense, uncertainty is not a weakness to be overcome, but the condition that makes genuine knowledge possible.

samples.prompt: Write a philosophical essay arguing a position on this question: Do we have stronger obligations to those near to us than to strangers? Take a clear stance and defend it with examples and reasoning. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
Nearness and Obligation: Why Proximity Matters Morally

Do we have stronger obligations to those near to us than to strangers? I argue that we do. While all persons possess equal moral worth, our obligations are not evenly distributed across humanity. Special obligations arising from proximity—familial, social, and institutional—are not moral defects to be overcome but essential features of a workable and humane moral life. Properly understood, partiality toward those near to us is not opposed to universal moral concern; it is one of the ways universal concern is made real.

At first glance, the claim that we owe more to those near to us seems to conflict with the idea of moral equality. If every human life matters equally, how can it be justified to favor one’s child over a stranger, or one’s neighbor over someone far away? Philosophers such as Peter Singer have pressed this challenge forcefully, arguing that distance and personal connection are morally irrelevant. If I can prevent serious harm at little cost to myself, it should not matter whether the person helped lives next door or on another continent.

This argument has considerable force, especially against moral complacency. Yet it overreaches. The mistake lies in assuming that moral equality requires identical obligations to all. Moral equality means that each person’s interests count; it does not mean that each person can make the same claim on each agent. The structure of moral responsibility depends not only on outcomes but also on relationships, roles, and expectations.

Consider the parent-child relationship. Parents are generally thought to have special obligations to their children: to feed them, protect them, educate them, and care for them in ways they are not obligated to do for other children. These obligations are not merely pragmatic conveniences; they are moral requirements. A parent who neglects their own child in order to donate all their resources to distant strangers is not morally admirable but morally deficient. This judgment would be inexplicable if proximity and relationship were morally irrelevant.

Why do such special obligations exist? One reason is that relationships generate legitimate expectations. Children are dependent on particular adults, not on humanity in general. Parents voluntarily bring children into the world or assume responsibility for them, thereby acquiring duties that others do not have. Similar reasoning applies to friendships, partnerships, and citizenship. Promises, shared histories, and mutual reliance create moral bonds that strangers lack.

Another reason proximity matters is that moral agency is distributed. If everyone had the same obligations to everyone else, responsibility would become diffuse and ineffective. Imagine a world in which no one felt special responsibility for the elderly neighbor down the street because “someone else somewhere” could help them. Moral life would collapse into abstraction. By assigning special obligations locally—to families, communities, and institutions—we ensure that someone is answerable for particular needs. Partiality, in this sense, is not a bias but a moral division of labor.

This division of labor also explains why special obligations can coexist with general duties. I may have a stronger obligation to help my sibling pay for emergency medical care than to donate the same amount to an anonymous stranger, but this does not absolve me of all duties to strangers. There are limits to permissible partiality. Favoring those near to us does not justify harming outsiders, ignoring extreme suffering, or perpetuating injustice. The claim is not that proximity trumps all other moral considerations, but that it legitimately intensifies obligation within moral bounds.

Real-world examples illustrate this balance. Governments prioritize the welfare of their own citizens through healthcare systems, social safety nets, and disaster response. This is widely regarded as morally appropriate, even though foreigners also have urgent needs. At the same time, most agree that wealthy nations have obligations to provide humanitarian aid and respond to global crises. Stronger obligations to compatriots do not negate weaker but still real obligations to others.

Critics worry that emphasizing proximity licenses nepotism, tribalism, or indifference to global suffering. This concern is justified if partiality is treated as unlimited or self-serving. But the alternative—demanding strict impartiality in all cases—risks moral alienation. Human moral psychology is deeply relational. Asking people to care for everyone equally often results not in heroic altruism but in moral paralysis or burnout. Ethics must be action-guiding for creatures like us, embedded in relationships and finite in attention and resources.

Moreover, special obligations can motivate broader moral concern. People often learn to care about humanity by first caring deeply about particular others. The practices of love, loyalty, and responsibility cultivated in close relationships are the training ground for justice, not its enemy.

In conclusion, we do have stronger obligations to those near to us than to strangers, and this is morally justified. Proximity creates relationships, expectations, and responsibilities that structure moral life and make care effective. Recognizing these special obligations does not deny the equal moral worth of all persons; it acknowledges the practical and ethical reality that morality must be lived locally even when it is justified universally. A moral world without partiality would not be more just—it would be less human.

samples.prompt: Write a philosophical essay arguing a position on this question: Is the examined life worth living if the examination reveals truths we cannot change? Take a clear stance and defend it with examples and reasoning. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
Is the Examined Life Worth Living When Truths Cannot Be Changed?

The examined life is worth living even when examination reveals truths we cannot change. Indeed, it is precisely the encounter with immovable realities—death, limitation, contingency, injustice—that gives examination its deepest value. To reject reflection because it uncovers unalterable facts is to confuse control with meaning. While examination may not grant us the power to revise the world, it grants something no less vital: the power to orient ourselves within it. An unexamined life may feel lighter, but it is thinner; it spares discomfort at the cost of depth.

The objection is intuitive. Why scrutinize one’s life if the scrutiny yields only resignation? Suppose examination reveals that one’s talents are limited, one’s past irreparable, one’s mortality unavoidable, or one’s social circumstances unjust yet fixed. What benefit comes from staring unblinkingly at walls we cannot move? This worry animates a long tradition of suspicion toward philosophy, from those who prefer consoling myths to Nietzsche’s charge that truth can be life-denying. If examination only strips away illusions without offering remedies, perhaps ignorance is kinder.

But this objection presumes that the primary aim of examination is to change outcomes. That is a mistake. The primary aim is to change understanding, and through it, agency. Even when facts are fixed, the meanings we assign, the priorities we adopt, and the responses we choose remain open. Examination does not promise mastery over circumstances; it promises clarity about them. And clarity, though sometimes painful, is the precondition for responsible choice.

Consider mortality. No amount of reflection will abolish death. Yet the examined recognition of mortality—central to the Stoics, to Epicurus, to existentialists—transforms how one lives. The unexamined person may drift as if time were infinite, postponing commitments and diluting attention. The examined person, knowing time is scarce, may love more deliberately, work more honestly, and forgive more readily. The fact of death is unchangeable; the posture one takes toward it is not. Examination converts an immovable truth into a compass.

The same is true of personal limitation. Suppose careful self-examination reveals that one will never be a great artist, athlete, or intellectual. This truth cannot be changed by willpower alone. Yet refusing to examine it often leads to self-deception, resentment, or the pursuit of borrowed lives. Examination can be liberating: it allows one to redirect energy toward attainable excellences, to value contribution over glory, or to appreciate goods previously obscured by unrealistic ambition. Here, truth narrows possibilities, but it also sharpens them. A narrowed field can be cultivated; a fantasy cannot.

Social and historical constraints pose a harder case. Many truths disclosed by examination—structural injustice, inherited disadvantage, historical trauma—are not only unchangeable for the individual but also morally appalling. Why examine a world that cannot be made fair? Yet examination here is indispensable to dignity. To live without understanding the forces that shape one’s life is to risk internalizing blame for harms one did not cause or mistaking survival for failure. Examination names the truth, and naming the truth is the first act of resistance, even when resistance cannot secure victory. It preserves self-respect by distinguishing what is one’s responsibility from what is not.

Moreover, examination fosters virtues that do not depend on altering facts: honesty, courage, humility, and compassion. An unexamined life may avoid despair, but it often does so by anesthetizing empathy. When we examine and acknowledge uncomfortable truths—about privilege, suffering, or complicity—we may feel burdened, yet we become more capable of solidarity. The examined life is worth living not because it makes us happier, but because it makes us more answerable to reality and to one another.

There is also a pragmatic argument. Avoidance is fragile. Unexamined truths do not vanish; they return as anxiety, projection, or fanaticism. A person who refuses to examine their fear of death may cling to distractions or dogmas; a society that refuses to examine its injustices may mythologize itself and lash out at critics. Examination stabilizes by integrating truth into a coherent narrative. Even when nothing can be changed, understanding reduces the psychic cost of denial.

This is not to deny the risks. Examination can curdle into rumination, paralysis, or nihilism. But these are failures of examination, not indictments of it. The examined life worth living is not one that merely accumulates bleak facts; it is one that asks how to live well given those facts. Socrates’ dictum was not a call to endless doubt but to ethical orientation. Examination aims at wisdom, not despair.

In the end, the question is not whether truth guarantees consolation—it does not—but whether meaning requires honesty. A life insulated from unchangeable truths may feel easier, yet it rests on borrowed time and borrowed stories. The examined life accepts the weight of what cannot be altered and still chooses how to stand. That choice—lucid, responsible, and humane—is enough to make such a life not only worth living, but worth respecting.

samples.prompt: Write a personal essay about a moment when you realized a long-held belief was wrong. Describe the context, the realization, and its aftermath. Use specific sensory details and emotional honesty. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
I used to believe that competence was loud.

I learned this belief early, in rooms where confidence announced itself before substance had time to catch up. In college seminars, the students who spoke first and longest seemed to own the material, even when their points were vague or wrong. At my first job, the people who filled meetings with decisive language—We should, The answer is, Obviously—were the ones who got nods and promotions. I absorbed it the way you absorb a smell without noticing: if you wanted to be taken seriously, you had to sound certain. Hesitation was weakness. Silence was absence.

By the time I was thirty, this belief had hardened into habit. In meetings, I spoke quickly, afraid that a pause would be mistaken for ignorance. I rehearsed sentences in my head while others were talking, the way an anxious driver watches only their own lane. When I didn’t know something, I dressed guesses in declarative verbs and hoped no one noticed the seams. It was exhausting, but it felt necessary—like gripping a steering wheel too tightly on a highway.

The moment that cracked this belief happened on a gray Tuesday afternoon, in a windowless conference room that smelled faintly of burnt coffee and dry-erase markers. We were reviewing a proposal I had helped draft, and I was ready to defend it. My heart thumped with the familiar mix of adrenaline and dread. The air conditioner hummed. Someone clicked a pen, again and again.

Then Maya spoke.

Maya was new, quiet, and unassuming in a way that made people underestimate her. She hadn’t said much in previous meetings, and when she did, her voice was soft, her sentences careful. I had clocked her as competent but passive—someone who would do good work and let louder people steer.

As the discussion circled, the room grew restless. Opinions stacked up like mismatched chairs. I felt the itch to jump in, to assert, to clarify. Before I could, Maya raised her hand slightly, as if testing the water.

“I might be missing something,” she said, and then paused.

The pause was long enough to make people look up from their laptops. I felt a flicker of irritation. Just say it, I thought. We’re running out of time.

She continued, slowly. “But if our goal is X, then this assumption here”—she tapped the document—“might actually push us in the opposite direction.”

She stopped again.

The room was quiet in a way that felt different—alert, not bored. I remember the faint buzz in my ears, the way you hear your own blood when everything else drops away. Someone leaned forward. Another person frowned, then nodded.

Maya didn’t rush to fill the silence. She let the idea sit there, unfinished, inviting scrutiny. And in that space, something happened: people began to think. Questions surfaced. The conversation shifted. Within minutes, it was clear that she was right, and that a flaw I had been prepared to defend was, in fact, a flaw.

I felt heat rise to my face—not just embarrassment, but something closer to grief. It wasn’t only that I had been wrong. It was that I had watched authority emerge from the very thing I’d been trained to avoid: uncertainty.

After the meeting, I replayed the moment in my head, the way you replay an accident in slow motion. Maya’s calm voice. The deliberate pauses. The absence of bravado. She hadn’t performed confidence; she had practiced honesty. She didn’t pretend to know everything. She made room for doubt, and in doing so, made room for truth.

The aftermath was not a single, clean change but a series of small, uncomfortable adjustments. The next time I didn’t know an answer, I tried saying, “I’m not sure.” My throat tightened around the words. The room didn’t collapse. No one laughed. In fact, someone else chimed in, relieved. Another time, I paused mid-sentence and let silence hang. It felt like standing on one foot, wobbling. But the conversation deepened instead of dying.

I began to notice things I’d missed before: how often the loudest voices repeated each other; how clarity sometimes arrived only after a stretch of quiet; how trust grew when people felt allowed to think out loud. I noticed my own body changing, too—the way my shoulders dropped when I stopped performing certainty, the way my breath slowed when I let myself listen fully instead of planning my next assertion.

The belief didn’t vanish overnight. It still flares up when I’m tired or afraid, whispering that I should speak faster, sound surer, take up more space. But now I recognize it for what it is: a shortcut masquerading as wisdom.

Competence, I’ve learned, is often quiet. It sounds like careful questions and measured words. It smells like cold coffee forgotten because someone was listening too closely to drink it. It feels like the steady relief of not having to pretend.

Letting go of the old belief didn’t make me smaller, as I once feared. It made me more present. And in the spaces where I used to rush to prove myself, something better has started to grow—understanding, shared ownership, and a confidence that doesn’t need to announce itself to be real.

samples.prompt: Write a personal essay about a place that shaped who you are. It might be a childhood home, a city you lived in, or somewhere you visited briefly but never forgot. Ground abstract reflections in concrete details. Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
The house where I grew up sat at the end of a gravel road that never quite decided whether it belonged to the town or to the fields beyond it. If you drove past the last mailbox, you would hear the sound change under your tires—from asphalt to loose stone—and that sound always felt like an announcement: you are entering a different pace of life now.

The house itself was unremarkable: a low, rectangular structure with beige siding that faded into the color of dust by late summer. But behind it stretched a narrow strip of woods, and beyond that, a creek that curved like a secret. This place shaped me not because it was dramatic or beautiful in the way postcards demand, but because it trained my attention. It taught me how to notice.

As a child, I spent hours outside, not out of virtue but because there was nothing else to do. The woods were small enough that I could not get lost, yet large enough to feel infinite. I learned the map of it by repetition: the fallen oak that smelled faintly of mushrooms, the thorn bush that always snagged my sleeves, the flat rock by the creek where the water slowed and turned glassy. In summer, the air was thick with cicadas, their sound vibrating through my ribs. In winter, the woods stripped themselves bare, and I could see how close the neighbors really were, their houses suddenly visible through the trees like truths revealed only in hardship.

Inside the house, details mattered just as much. The kitchen floor was linoleum patterned with tiny blue flowers, and it always felt cold, even in July. The refrigerator hummed loudly enough that you had to raise your voice when standing next to it. At night, lying in bed, I could hear the house settling—soft pops and creaks, as if it were thinking. These sounds became a language of safety. Silence, I learned, is not always comforting; sometimes it means something has gone wrong.

That house taught me about boundaries. My bedroom window faced the woods, and I learned early how much I could see and how much remained hidden. At night, the glass reflected my own face back at me, superimposed over the dark trees. I grew accustomed to that layered vision: the self and the world occupying the same frame. Even now, I think that is how I move through life—aware that every view is partial, that reflection is always involved.

The place also taught me about waiting. The bus came early, and in winter I stood at the end of the gravel road, breath puffing white, toes numb despite thick socks. I watched the sky change color minute by minute, from indigo to pale gray to something almost hopeful. Waiting there, I learned patience not as a moral lesson but as a physical experience. You wait because there is nothing else to do. You endure. You notice.

When I finally left that house, I thought I was leaving it behind. I moved to places with sidewalks and streetlights, where the night buzzed instead of hummed. But I carried the habits of that place with me. In new cities, I learned neighborhoods the way I learned the woods—by walking without headphones, by memorizing corners and smells and the way light hit certain buildings at certain times of day. I noticed when a space felt too quiet, or when noise masked something uneasy.

What I did not realize until much later was that the place also shaped how I understand belonging. The gravel road was a threshold: once you crossed it, you were almost home, but not quite. That in-between state became familiar, even comfortable. I am at ease now in liminal spaces—airports, waiting rooms, transitional moments—because my first sense of home was never sharply defined. It was approached gradually, announced by sound and texture rather than signs.

When I visit now, the house looks smaller. The woods have thinned, and the creek runs lower than I remember. But the gravel road is still there, and the sound under the tires still signals a shift. Each time I hear it, something in me slows down. I am reminded that who I am was shaped not by grand events, but by small, repeated encounters with a single place. A place that taught me to listen, to wait, and to pay attention to what is quietly, persistently present.

samples.prompt: Write a personal essay about a skill or practice you learned later in life than most. What was difficult about it? What did it reveal about yourself? Approximately 800 words.
samples.text:
I learned how to swim when I was thirty-four.

This is an awkward confession in a culture that treats swimming as a childhood rite of passage, on par with riding a bike or tying shoelaces. Most people I know don’t remember learning to swim; they remember already knowing how. For me, water had always been a place of spectatorship rather than participation. I sat on the edge of pools with my feet dangling, volunteered to hold towels at the beach, perfected the art of staying dry while appearing relaxed. I told myself I didn’t like swimming. It was easier than admitting I was afraid.

The fear was not dramatic. I wasn’t haunted by a single traumatic near-drowning. Instead, it was quieter and more corrosive: a steady conviction that my body did not belong in deep water. As a child, I missed lessons for ordinary reasons—money, logistics, the assumption that I would “pick it up later.” Later never came. By adulthood, the gap felt unbridgeable. How do you begin something at an age when you’re supposed to be competent at everything?

What made learning difficult wasn’t just the mechanics—coordinating arms, legs, breath—but the humiliation of being visibly bad at something in public. Swimming pools are terrible places to be a beginner. The water is clear, the movements are large, and everyone else seems effortlessly fluent. I was surrounded by children half my size slicing through lanes, elderly swimmers chatting between laps, teenagers doing butterfly for fun. Meanwhile, I clung to the wall, rehearsing failure.

The first lesson was brutal in its simplicity. “Blow bubbles,” the instructor said, as if this were a reasonable request for a grown adult with a mortgage. My rational brain understood the physics. My body did not care. The moment my face touched the water, panic flared—tight chest, frantic thoughts, the certainty that I was about to drown in a perfectly controlled environment. I surfaced coughing, embarrassed by how quickly fear had overridden logic.

Progress was slow and uneven. Some weeks I felt triumphant for floating unassisted for ten seconds; other weeks I regressed, convinced I had imagined the improvement. Learning to swim forced me to confront how impatient I am with myself. I expected mastery quickly, as if adulthood came with an invisible badge that exempted me from awkward beginnings. Each failure felt like a referendum on my competence as a person, not just a data point in the learning process.

What surprised me most was how physical the lesson became about trust—trusting my body, the water, and the incremental nature of learning. Swimming is an act of cooperation with something stronger than you. You don’t conquer water; you negotiate with it. When I fought it, I sank. When I stiffened, I flailed. Only when I relaxed—an instruction that sounds infuriatingly vague until you experience it—did I float.

This was not a metaphor I was eager to accept. I prefer effort, control, visible striving. Swimming taught me that some skills require yielding rather than pushing, patience rather than force. You can’t muscle your way into buoyancy. You have to believe, at least a little, that the water will hold you.

Learning later in life also stripped away the illusion that everyone else knows what they’re doing. Once I started paying attention, I noticed how many adults avoid pools the way I once did. How many confessions surfaced quietly: “I never really learned either.” My shame was not unique; it was just well hidden. The difference was that I had decided, finally, to be bad at something on purpose.

The day I swam my first full length of the pool was anticlimactic. No applause, no swelling music. I reached the wall, breathing hard, and felt a small, solid joy settle in my chest. It wasn’t pride so much as relief. I had proven something modest but important to myself: fear was not a permanent condition. It was a habit, and habits can be changed.

Swimming didn’t transform me into a fearless person. I still hesitate before unfamiliar depths, literal and otherwise. But it recalibrated my relationship with discomfort. It taught me that learning late is not a moral failure, that embarrassment is survivable, and that competence is often built quietly, stroke by awkward stroke.

Now, when I enter a pool, I slide in without ceremony. I swim slow, ungraceful laps. I am still not good. But I am there, moving forward in water that once felt impossible. And that, I’ve learned, counts for more than starting early ever did.
